etymologies: early 19th century: from Latin ultra ‘beyond’ and crepida ‘shoe, sandal’, with allusion to the remark ne supra crepidam sutor iudicaret ‘the cobbler should not judge beyond his shoe’, attributed to the painter Apelles of Kos in response to criticism from a shoemaker in Pliny the Elder's Natural History (AD 77)

definitions: expressing opinions on matters outside the scope of one's knowledge or expertise

examples.text: “Dad, how do we know the universe is expanding?” inquires your six-year-old. Try answering that without resorting to an ultracrepidarian trick here or there

shortDefinitions: expressing opinions on matters outside one's knowledge

definitions: a person who expresses opinions on matters outside the scope of their knowledge or expertise

examples.text: most patients are ultracrepidarians when it comes to medicine

shortDefinitions: person who expresses opinions on matters outside their knowledge
